Solve problems that can be modeled using exponential and logarithmic equations, interpret the solutions, and determine whether the solutions are reasonable using technology as appropriate.
Sequences and Series
Write the recursive formula for arithmetic and geometric sequences and find specified terms of arithmetic and geometric sequences.
Write the formula for the general term for arithmetic and geometric sequences and make connections to linear and exponential functions.
Find partial sums of arithmetic and geometric series.

Solve problems involving applications that can be modeled using sequences and finite arithmetic and geometric series. Interpret the solutions and determine whether the solutions are reasonable using spreadsheets as appropriate.

Standard 2
Geometry and Measurement
Identify and apply properties of and theorems about parallel and perpendicular lines and write equations of parallel and perpendicular lines.
Identify, justify and apply properties of planes.

Represent geometric objects and figures algebraically using coordinates, use algebra to solve geometric problems, and develop simple coordinate proofs involving geometric objects in the coordinate plane.
Describe the intersection of two or more geometric figures in the plane.
Construct triangles congruent to given triangles, explaining and justifying the process used.
Prove and apply the triangle inequality theorem.
Develop simple geometric proofs involving triangles and provide reasons for each statement.

Find the equation of a circle in the coordinate plane in terms of its center and radius and determine how the graph of a circle changes if a, b, and r are changed in the equation (x – a)² + (y – b)² = r².
Visualize solids and surfaces in three-dimensional space when given two-dimensional representations and create two-dimensional representations for the surfaces of three-dimensional objects.
Find and use measures of sides, volumes, and surface areas of prisms, regular pyramids, cylinders, right circular cones and spheres. Relate these measures to each other using formulas.

Standard 3
Data Analysis and Statistics
Use simulations to explore the variability of sample statistics from a known population and to construct sampling distributions.

Evaluate published reports that are based on data by examining the design of the study, the appropriateness of the data analysis, and the validity of conclusions. Interpret confidence levels and "margin of error."
Compare the difference among surveys, experiments and observational studies and recognize which types of inferences can legitimately be drawn from each.
Compute basic statistics (mean, median, weighted mean, range, variance, standard deviation) and understand the distinction between a statistic and a parameter.
Understand the meaning of measurement data and categorical data, of univariate and bivariate data, and of the term variable.
Use simulations to construct empirical probability distributions.
Apply the properties of the normal distribution.
Compute and interpret the expected value of random variables in simple cases.
Compute the probability of compound events.
Model and solve problems, including probability problems, using counting techniques.

Standard 4
Discrete Mathematics
Know and use the concepts of sets, elements, and subsets.
Perform operations on sets (union, intersection, complement, cross product).
Identify and give examples of undefined terms, axioms, and theorems.
Describe logical statements using the terms assumption, hypothesis, conclusion, converse, inverse, and contrapositive. Find the converse, inverse, and contrapositive of statements.

Explain and illustrate the role of definitions, conjectures, theorems, proofs and counterexamples in mathematical reasoning. Construct logical arguments, assess the validity of logical arguments and give counterexamples to disprove statements.
Model and solve problems involving patterns using recursion and iteration, growth and decay, and compound interest.
Use mathematical induction to prove simple propositions.
Use graph-coloring techniques to solve problems.
Use bin-packing techniques to solve problems of optimizing resource usage.

Standard 1
Relations and Functions

Use paper and pencil methods and technology to graph polynomial, absolute value, rational, algebraic, exponential, logarithmic, trigonometric, inverse trigonometric and piecewise-defined functions, use these graphs to solve problems, and translate among verbal, tabular, graphical, and symbolic representations of functions using technology as appropriate.
Identify domain, range, intercepts, zeros, asymptotes, and points of discontinuity of functions represented symbolically or graphically, using technology as appropriate.
Solve word problems that can be modeled using functions and equations.
Recognize and describe continuity, end behavior, asymptotes, symmetry, and limits and connect these concepts to graphs of functions.
Find, interpret, and graph the sum, difference, product, and quotient (when it exists) of two functions, indicating the relevant domain and range of the resulting function.

Find the composition of two functions, and determine the domain and the range of the composite function. Conversely, given a function, find two other functions the composition of which is the given one.
Define and find inverse functions, their domains and ranges, and verify whether two given functions are inverses of each other, symbolically and graphically.
Apply transformations to functions and interpret the results of these transformations verbally, graphically, and numerically.

Standard 2
Conics
Derive equations for conic sections and use the equations that have been found.
Graph conic sections with axes of symmetry parallel to the coordinate axes by hand, by completing the square, and find the foci, center, asymptotes, eccentricity, axes, and vertices (as appropriate).

Standard 3
Logarithmic and Exponential Functions
Compare and contrast y = e<sup>x</sup> with other exponential functions, symbolically and graphically.

Define the logarithmic function g(x) = log<sub>a</sub> x as the inverse of the exponential function f(x) = a<sup>x</sup>. Apply the inverse relationship between exponential and logarithmic functions and the laws of logarithms to solve problems.
Analyze, describe, and sketch graphs of logarithmic and exponential functions by examining intercepts, zeros, domain and range, and asymptotic and end behavior.
Solve problems that can be modeled using logarithmic and exponential functions. Interpret the solutions, and determine whether the solutions are reasonable.

Standard 4
Trigonometry
Define and use the trigonometric ratios cotangent, secant, and cosecant in terms of angles of right triangles.
Model and solve problems involving triangles using trigonometric ratios.
Develop and use the laws of sines and cosines to solve problems.
Define sine and cosine using the unit circle.
Develop and use radian measures of angles, measure angles in degrees and radians, and convert between degree and radian measures.
Deduce geometrically and use the value of the sine, cosine, and tangent functions at 0, π/6, π/4, π/3, and π/2 radians and their multiples.
Make connections between right triangle ratios, trigonometric functions, and the coordinate function on the unit circle.

Analyze and graph trigonometric functions, including the translation of these trigonometric functions. Describe their characteristics (spread, amplitude, zeros, symmetry, phase, shift, vertical shift, frequency).
Define, analyze and graph inverse trigonometric functions and find the values of inverse trigonometric functions.
Solve problems that can be modeled using trigonometric functions, interpret the solutions, and determine whether the solutions are reasonable.

Derive the fundamental Pythagorean trigonometric identities, sum and difference identities, half-angle and double-angle identities and the secant, cosecant, and cotangent functions and use these identities to verify other identities and simplify trigonometric expressions.
Solve trigonometric equations and interpret solutions graphically.

Standard 5
Polar Coordinates and Complex Numbers
Define and use polar coordinates and relate polar coordinates to Cartesian coordinates.
Represent equations given in Cartesian coordinates in terms of polar coordinates.
Graph equations in the polar coordinate plane.
Define complex numbers, convert complex numbers to polar form, and multiply complex numbers in polar form.
Prove and use De Moivre's Theorem.

Standard 6
Sequences and Series
Define arithmetic and geometric sequences and series.
Derive and use formulas for finding the general term for arithmetic and geometric sequences.
Develop, prove and use sum formulas for arithmetic series and for finite and infinite geometric series.
Generate a sequence using recursion.

Describe the concept of the limit of a sequence and a limit of a function. Decide whether simple sequences converge or diverge, and recognize an infinite series as the limit of a sequence of partial sums.
Model and solve word problems involving applications of sequences and series, interpret the solutions and determine whether the solutions are reasonable.
Derive the binomial theorem by combinatorics.

Standard 7
Vectors and Parametric Equations
Define vectors as objects having magnitude and direction and represent vectors geometrically.
Use parametric equations to represent situations involving motion in the plane.
Convert between a pair of parametric equations and an equation in x and y
Analyze planar curves, including those given in parametric form.
Model and solve problems using parametric equations.

Standard 8
Data Analysis
Use linear models using the median fit and least squares regression methods. Decide which among several linear models gives a better fit. Interpret the slope in terms of the original context
Calculate and interpret the correlation coefficient. Use the correlation coefficient and residuals to evaluate a "best-fit" line.
